meaning: a person who spoils other people's fun.
f: He's a wet blanket at parties because he only talks about depressing topics
l: He's a wet blanket because he spilled his cup of water all over himself

meaning: a test that proves a hypothesis or validity of a product or idea
f: It was an acid test to see if I have what it takes to succeed in this field
l: It was an acid test since we used pH paper to measure acidity levels

meaning: more successful than other people who are trying to achieve the same things
a: He is ahead of the pack
f: He is ahead of the pack because of his hard work and dedication to his goals
l: He is ahead of the pack because he runs faster than anyone else

meaning: used to convey that you cannot understand what is being said or written
a: This seems all Greek to me
f: This seems all Greek to me as I can't comprehend it with my current knowledge
l: This seems all Greek to me as I can't understand the Greek words

meaning: in a straight line
a: We took a journey as the crow flies
f: We took a journey as the crow flies without any stops along the way
l: We took a journey as the crow flies, following the crow's actual path from one point to another

meaning: failing to attend to one's responsibilities or duties
a: He was asleep at the switch
f: He was asleep at the switch and missed out on the opportunity
l: He was asleep at the switch and woke up late for the train

meaning: to keep something dangerous at a safe distance
f: She kept him at bay with her sarcastic remarks
l: She kept him at bay with a barricade

meaning: to the core of the object
f: It's at the bottom of my priority list
l: It's at the bottom of the river

meaning: It means to be on wager or bet, when there is some sort of uncertainty.
f: Everything is at stake as the future of our marriage depends on it
l: Everything is at stake as the pieces are laid out on the game board

idiom: at the drop of a dime
meaning: something that can happen very fast without hesitation
a: He moved at the drop of a dime
f: He moved at the drop of a dime as he had been waiting to make that decision for a while
l: He moved at the drop of a dime as he had heard the sound of a coin falling on the ground

meaning: to admit that you were wrong about something and apologize
f: He ate crow yesterday when he had to apologize for his mistake
l: He ate crow yesterday as part of a dare

meaning: to be in a difficult situation
f: I'm up against the wall, feeling burdened by the weight of all the problems in my life
l: I'm up against the wall because I'm not able to move more around

meaning: to suddenly begin to understand
a: He has begun to see the light
f: He has begun to see the light in terms of understanding the subject better
l: He has begun to see the light as the sun has come up

idiom: bite off more than one can chew
meaning: to try to do something that is too difficult for you, or more than you can manage
a: He bit off more than he could chew
f: He bit off more than he could chew when he accepted that extra responsibility
l: He bit off more than he could chew when he tried to fit an entire slice of pizza in his mouth

meaning: to endure a painful experience that you cannot avoid
a: You have to bite the bullet
f: You have to bite the bullet and accept the tough decision that was made
l: You have to bite the bullet as that's the only way to get it out from your arm

meaning: to turn against someone who has been a benefactor in the past
a: It was biting the hand that fed him
f: It was biting the hand that fed him when it caused damage to the company that employed him
l: It was biting the hand that fed him when it ate away the food from the plate

meaning: miscellaneous small objects
a: They told me bits and pieces
f: They told me bits and pieces of their story, so I'm not sure I have the full picture
l: They told me bits and pieces, so I put the object they were describing together

meaning: good luck
f: He broke a leg on stage when he delivered an outstanding performance
l: He broke a leg after he fell down the stairs

meaning: end a romantic relationship with someone
f: They broke up because they couldn't agree on how to spend their holidays
l: They broke up the firewood, which they had spent a few hours cutting

meaning: to have a secret advantage that is suddenly revealed to change the game
a: He had a card up his sleeve
f: He had a card up his sleeve when he went into the meeting, which allowed him to surprise everyone with his unexpected solution
l: He had a card up his sleeve when he went into the meeting, as he wanted to provide visual aids for his presentation

meaning: someone is not likely to succeed, especially because the person is not being given a fair chance
a: The cards are stacked against him
f: The cards are stacked against him because he doesn't have the same opportunities as others
l: The cards are stacked against him because he is not good at card games

meaning: to take something to a place or a person that has a lot of that thing already
a: He's already carrying coals to Newcastle
f: He's already carrying coals to Newcastle, trying to convince his boss to change her mind
l: He's already carrying coals to Newcastle, since coal is the main export of the region

meaning: to have friendly banter for hours on end.
f: We were chewing the fat and catching up
l: We were chewing the fat to see if it was edible

meaning: repeatedly change.
f: I'm always chopping and changing what I'll do this weekend
l: I'm always chopping and changing this recipe with different ingredients

meaning: a narrow escape
f: That was a close shave when I narrowly avoided an accident on the highway
l: That was a close shave when I used my razor to give myself a very close shave

meaning: loss of courage
f: He got cold feet and decided to back out of the wedding at the last minute
l: He got cold feet when he put on his socks

meaning: to be busy with something
f: They have concerns with it as it will cause more problems
l: They have concerns with it as they think it could be improved

meaning: to spoil someone's chances of success
f: He cooked his goose when he put his entire life savings on the stock market
l: He cooked his goose for dinner and it was delicious

meaning: to do what someone else forces you to do
f: She dances to their tune, meaning she does as they say
l: She dances to their tune, matching their rhythmic music

meaning: felt strongly and often hidden from other people
f: She knew deep down that spending more time with her family was the right decision
l: She knew deep down in her subconscious mind

meaning: disappear or change very slowly, take a long time to cease to exist or be dropped from consideration. Noun: a person who displays such resistance or loyalty. Example 1: Die hard boarders are snatching up second homes here, but so far it has managed to stay affordable. Example 2: Die-hard football enthusiasts were planning the rebirth of a town team. Example 3: On the morning of my visit, a few die-hards were setting up a small fund-raising event at the gro
a: She is a die hard fan
f: She is a die hard fan of the band and she has been a fan of them since she was a kid
l: She is a die hard fan since she managed to survive their concert in the extreme heat of the summer

meaning: to narrowly avoid a very serious problem or a disaster
f: I dodged a bullet when she said she was willing to forgive me
l: I dodged a bullet when it whizzed past me

meaning: something that could either help you or hurt you
f: This is a double-edged sword because it has both advantages and disadvantages
l: This is a double-edged sword since it has two sharp sides

meaning: delaying in decision, not showing enthusiasm
a: The government is dragging its feet
f: The government is dragging its feet when it comes to passing this new bill
l: The government is dragging its feet across the street

meaning: to make someone angry or irritated
a: He drove me up the wall
f: He drove me up the wall when he started asking too many questions
l: He drove me up the wall when he took me for a car ride

meaning: an informal visit
f: I dropped by yesterday to get my job application checked
l: I dropped by yesterday to deliver a package

meaning: make a bad situation even worse
f: He fanned the flames by exciting the argument further
l: He fanned the flames of the campfire to keep it going

meaning: trying to do something even when there is little chance of succeeding
f: He's fighting a losing battle to get his point across
l: He's fighting a losing battle since none of his punches are landing

meaning: show someone the middle finger as an act of contempt or anger
f: She flipped the bird after hearing what he had to say
l: She flipped the bird to fly away

meaning: when you want someone to open a hand so you can hit it with your open hand in greeting or celebration
f: Can you give me five to show your support for this cause?
l: Can you give me five to high-five me?

meaning: good gardening results
f: He has a green thumb as he was able to make even the most difficult plants thrive and bloom
l: He has a green thumb due to a spray he often uses for his plants

meaning: when someone has completely failed in what they set out to achieve
f: We've had our chips and now it's time to move on
l: We've had our chips for lunch

meaning: close ties or connections

l: We walked hand in hand to keep our balance on the beach

meaning: to not be able to do anything about a situation
f: Our hands are tied due to the regulations set by the board of directors
l: Our hands are tied due to the rope around them

meaning: to have a great time
a: We had a ball last night
f: We had a ball last night when we went out to the club and danced the night away
l: We had a ball last night as we kicked it around the living room

meaning: to feel extremely anxious or nervous faced with a dangerous or unpleasant situation
a: He had a heart in his mouth
f: He had a heart in his mouth while giving his presentation as he was very anxious
l: He had a heart in his mouth because he was eating an organ meat dish

meaning: to show modesty towards something or someone
a: We shouldn't hide our light under a bushel

meaning: to be exactly right about something or achieve the best result possible

meaning: to start a new job or activity without being prepared for it

l: She jumped in at the deep end of the swimming pool

meaning: in trouble or state of shame

meaning: because of

meaning: work that someone in an important position gives to their friends or relations

meaning: when there is no general agreement or consensus on something

meaning: manage to stay alive with very little money

l: He was trying to keep body and soul together by eating the barest minimum of food

meaning: to stay informed

meaning: the last thing you would do if you were desperate and all other courses of action had failed

meaning: make someone act or think in a wrong or foolish manner.

meaning: progress very quickly

meaning: not have control over your emotions

meaning: go insane or crazy

meaning: to not know something.

meaning: Someone who is old fashioned. The phrase can directly refer to old fashion too.

meaning: to be better than what went before
